item.title: Trump’s 50% Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum Imports Go Into Effect
item.description: The president has ratcheted up the rate on foreign metals to 50 percent, double the previous rate, saying the levies weren’t high enough to help the U.S. industry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Ian Austen

item.title: U.S.-China Trade War Morphs From Tariffs Into Fight Over Supply Chain
item.description: Instead of battling over tariffs, Washington and Beijing have turned to a potentially far more harmful strategy: flexing their control over global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Will Drag Down the Global Economy, OECD Says
item.description: Economic growth will slow this year and next as the trade war hampers development in the United States and around the world, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: As Courts Call Tariffs Into Question, Trump Again Turns to His Favorite Tool
item.description: The president is set to raise tariffs on steel and aluminum this week, even as the courts are challenging the legitimacy of other levies.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tony Romm

item.title: Trump Officials Unveil Budget Cuts to Aid for Health, Housing and Research
item.description: The new blueprint shows that a vast array of education, health, housing and labor programs would be hit, including aid for college and cancer research.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Trump Makes a New Push to ‘Decouple’ U.S. From China
item.description: Trump administration officials are getting a second chance to try to sever ties with China by starting a trade war, imposing export controls and revoking student visas.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong

item.title: Trump Accuses China of Violating Trade Agreement
item.description: President Trump said that Beijing was not honoring the terms of a temporary agreement and warned of further confrontation.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Tony Romm and Ana Swanson

item.title: How Skateboarders Helped Rebuild San Francisco’s U.N. Plaza
item.description: Made quickly and with minimal fuss, a park for skateboarders revived a downtown site — and offered a few lessons for urban revitalization.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty and Loren Elliott

item.title: Tariff Ruling Gives Businesses Hope, but They’re Soon Unmoored Again
item.description: Companies welcomed a court decision striking down President Trump’s tariffs. Then a stay of that ruling left no one breathing easy.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Trump Criticizes the Fed in a Private Meeting With Powell
item.description: Jerome H. Powell stressed in his first meeting since the president returned to the White House that policy decisions would be “based solely on careful, objective and nonpolitical analysis.”
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Drive a Rise in Trade Crime
item.description: President Trump’s steep global tariffs have supercharged efforts to evade them. Some U.S. companies say the government is ill equipped to keep up.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Lazaro Gamio

item.title: U.S. Pauses Exports of Airplane and Semiconductor Technology to China
item.description: President Trump has stopped some critical products and technologies made only in the United States from flowing to China, flexing the government’s power over global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump’s Plan to Revive US Shipbuilding Would Take Billions and Many Years
item.description: President Trump and members of Congress want to revive U.S. shipbuilding with subsidies and penalties against Chinese-built ships. But there are obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis

item.title: Pivoting From Tax Cuts to Tariffs, Trump Ignores Economic Warning Signs
item.description: The president’s economic policy approach is so far rattling markets, businesses and consumers.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Colby Smith

item.title: Under Trump, the Small Business Administration Clamps Down
item.description: At the Small Business Administration, deep staffing cuts and stricter loan terms are making it harder for entrepreneurs to get access to capital, contracts and technical assistance.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Have You Seen Evidence of Trade Crime? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: The New York Times is looking to talk to business owners and employees who have seen evidence of tariff dodging or customs fraud.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Berates Walmart and Mattel for Warning About Tariff Price Increases
item.description: The president recently attacked Walmart, saying it should “eat” the costs rather than pass them on to customers.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: G7 Officials Gather Amid Headwinds From Trump’s Trade War
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will meet his international counterparts at a G7 finance ministers meeting in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump’s Computer Chip Deals With Saudi Arabia and UAE Divide US Government
item.description: Big deals to sell chips to the U.A.E. and Saudi Arabia have divided the U.S. government over whether they could be remembered for shipping cutting-edge A.I. overseas.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Ana Swanson

item.title: Funeral Homes Are Forced to Innovate as Consumer Preferences Shift
item.description: As cremation rates rise and consumer preferences shift, funeral homes are innovating in surprisingly unconventional ways so they don’t die out.
item.dc:creator: Susan Shain
